Fig. 1 Schematic illustration for the synthesis of Fe-N-C catalysts (a); SEM samples of Fe-N-C before (b) and after pyrolysis at 900 °C (c); HAADF-STEM images of Fe-N-C900 catalysts at different magnifications: (d) and (e) 200 nm and 2 nm; TEM image of Fe-N-C900 catalysts (f). Fig. 2 XRD patterns of DAP-DAN900 Fe-N-C900 catalyst before and after acid leaching (a); XRD patterns of the catalysts prepared at different pyrolysis temperatures (b); Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms (c) and pore size distribution (d). Graphical abstract In spite of the recent advancements, rational design and synthesis of non-precious metal oxygen redox catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in both alkaline and acidic media is still a crucial challenge for the development of rechargeable metal-air batteries and regenerative fuel cells. Heteroatom doped carbon-based materials exhibit a promising strategy to achieve the bifunctionality within one catalyst. Herein, we report a highly efficient Fe-N-C oxygen redox catalyst derived from a new class of Fe coordinated bis(imino)-pyridine ligand based polymer synthesized via Schiff base condensation between 2,6-diacetylpyridine and 1,8-diaminonaphthalene. The Fe-N-C catalyst prepared by this precursor without templates or supports is characterized by spherical structure, ultrahigh specific surface area up to 1796.0 m2/g, a high degree of graphitization and atomically dispersed five-coordinated Fe-N5 sites. These unique features endow the catalyst with outperforming performance for ORR and OER in terms of remarkable activity and stability in both alkaline and acidic media. The overall oxygen redox activity (ΔE = Ej=10 − E1/2) (0.70 V in alkaline media and 0.86 V in acidic media) of the catalyst for both ORR and OER is much higher than those of none precious metal catalysts previously reported. These outstanding features remark the great possibility of the introduced catalyst for the practical application. Keywords Oxygen redox catalyst Single-atom catalysis Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Fe-Nx sites 1 Introduction Sustainable energy conversion and storage systems such as rechargeable metal-air batteries and regenerative fuel cells are considered as promising technologies to meet the increasing demands for renewable energy due to their high energy densities, high efficiency, simple construction, steady operation, and being environmentally benign [1–3]. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are the key processes for these devices [4–6]. However, both OER and ORR processes are kinetically sluggish, attributed to the electron-transfer processes (4e− reactions) and complex reaction pathways which require catalysts to accelerate the reactions [7–10]. Up to date, the catalyst materials for ORR and OER still mainly focus on the precious metals. While platinum (Pt)-based noble metals are considered as the most efficient commercial electrocatalysts for ORR [8,9,11–15], their performance is not satisfying in the case of OER. On the other hand, IrO2 and RuO2 catalysts are extensively used for the OER process because of their excellent performance [16–18] but show poor response toward ORR [19]. Moreover, the high cost and scarcity of these materials have seriously hindered the widespread development of energy conversion and storage systems [8]. Therefore, it is of great importance to design and develop alternative materials with improved catalytic performance to replace the precious metal catalysts. Specifically, introduction of a non-expensive bifunctional catalyst which can unify both catalysts for ORR and OER and perform effectively in both acidic and basic media is highly desirable for practical application [20]. To achieve this aim, researchers have extensively investigated several bifunctional non-noble metal catalyst for ORR and OER including perovskites [21,22], transition metal oxides [23-25], sulfides [26,27], phosphides [28] and carbides/nitrides [29], and carbon-based nanomaterials [30,31]. Among these catalysts, it is believed that carbon-based materials are the most promising for ORR and OER, because of their outstanding activity, high stability and low cost. Particularly, transition metal-nitrogen doped carbon (M-N-C) [19,32] such as Fe-N-C composition has been confirmed to show an efficient ORR catalytic activity due to the presence of Fe-Nx active sites [33,34] and a great deal of researches have been already dedicated to search this area. Nevertheless, there are a few reports regarding their OER activity and normally the reported results are not comparable with that of precious metal (oxides) in terms of both stability and performance [35]. Conventional methods for incorporation of the Fe-Nx sites into the carbon framework are through employing expensive iron macrocycles such as iron phetalocyanines or pyrolysis of metal, nitrogen-containing polymers such as polyacrylonitrile (PAN), polypyrrole (PPy), polyaniline (PANI), ethylenediamine (EN), and cyanamide (CA) at elevated temperatures [36,37]. To govern a high catalytic activity, it is critical to tune the catalyst structure so that a high surface area would be achieved to efficiently increase the total number of accessible active sites. Moreover, the catalyst needs to be rich in micro/mesopores can provide an ample electrode/electrolyte interface for ion or charge accumulation performance during the ORR and OER processes [38]. A simple pyrolysis step, however, results only in agglomerated particles with low surface area [39]. In this context, some researchers employed a template such as silica colloids or mesoporous ordered silica for nanostructuring, the resulted Fe-N-C catalyst could reach a high surface area of 572 m2·g−1 [40]. Alternatively, groups used a micro-mesoporous carbon material with a high surface area [41] to achieve a highly porous structure after pyrolysis. Recently, there has been an interest on employing metal organic frameworks (MOFs) for designing M-N-C catalysts which offers the possibility of tuning active site with dispersed single metal atoms coordinated by nitrogen atoms [42]. Lai et al. [43], reported a host-guest strategy using zeolite imidazole framework-8 (ZIF-8) to build Fe-N-C catalyst with abundant Fe-Nx active sites for ORR and achieved a maximum surface area of 1036 m2·g−1. Despite these advantages, the graphitization in these materials is mainly of unsatisfying degree which is not suitable for the ion and electron transfer [44]. Therefore, searching for novel and low-cost synthesis methods is urgently needed to fill this gap. One way to fulfill this goal is obviously through rational design of the precursors as it can exert a profound effect on the physical and chemical properties of the subsequent catalysts [45,46]. Herein, we report a simple and straightforward strategy for the preparation of a self-supported highly porous Fe-N-C carbon-based oxygen electrocatalyst with single atoms of iron dispersed throughout the structure by designing a new organo-metallic complex. The Fe-N-C material was in fact synthesized via pyrolysis of poly{2,6-bis-[2-(N-(8-amino-naphthalen-1-yl)-imino)ethyl] pyridine} iron trichloride complex spheres using 2,6-Diacetylpyridine (DAP) and 1,8-Diamino-naphthalene (DAN) as precursors for both carbon and nitrogen together with FeCl3·6H2O as the iron source. The catalyst features a well-defined spherical morphology of nitrogen doped graphitic carbon matrix decorated with single iron atoms coordinated with nitrogen and an ultra-high surface area of 1796 m2/g without using any supports or templates. The synthesized catalyst has excellent ORR and OER performances with high reactivity and selectivity, far superior to the previously reported catalysts (Table 1 ). The catalyst delivers a half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.91 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) in 0.1 M KOH for ORR, 32 mV higher than that of commercial Pt/C (E1/2 of 0.88 V and the corresponding E1/2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 is 0.80 V, which currently ranks among the most active Fe-N-C catalysts previously reported. The catalyst also demonstrated a remarkable stability in both alkaline and acidic solutions, surpassing Pt/C. Meanwhile, the catalytic activity of the catalyst was investigated for OER which interestingly displayed an excellent performance in both acidic and alkaline media with a higher activity than that of Pt/C. The overall oxygen activity (ΔE = Ej=10 − E1/2) of the Fe-N-C900 catalyst for ORR and OER is much higher than those of none precious metal catalysts previously reported (Table 1). These outstanding features remark the possibility of mass scale production of the introduced catalyst for practical application purposes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 2,6-Diacetylpyridine (DAP, 98.0%), 1,8-Diaminonaphthalene (DAN, 99%), Iron(III) chloride hexahydrate, oxalic acid and ethyl alcohol absolute were all AR grade and used as received without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of Fe-N-C catalysts The Fe-N-C catalysts were synthesized via pyrolysis of poly{2,6-bis-[2-(N-(8-amino-naphthalen-1-yl)-imino)ethyl] pyridine} iron trichloride complex spheres. The synthesis is briefly described in the following: DAP (200 mg) and DAN (194 mg) was dissolved in ethyl alcohol absolute (10 mL) solution together with oxalic acid (12 mg) as catalyst to accomplish a dehydration reaction, under magnetic stirring at 60 °C for 12 h. Then, FeCl3·6H2O (331 mg) was added to the mixture solution under vigorous magnetic stirring, at room temperature for 12 h to form poly{2,6-bis-[2-(N-(8-amino-naphthalen-1-yl)-imino)ethyl] pyridine} iron trichloride complex. The samples were dried using a rotary evaporator under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h, after which they were ground using mortar and pestle. The pyrolysis process was then carried out under the protection of purged nitrogen, with a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1, and a dwelling time of 2 h at different heat treatment temperatures of 700 °C, 800 °C, 900 °C and 1000 °C, respectively. The corresponding catalysts were labeled as Fe-N-C700, Fe-N-C800, Fe-N-C900 and Fe-N-C1000, respectively. The heat-treated products were then chemically etched in 0.5 M H2SO4 at 80 °C for 8 h to remove the unstable and inactive species from the catalysts followed by suction filtration and rinsing with the deionized (DI) water for several times until the liquid became neutral. The catalysts were finally dried under vacuum for 6 h at 80 °C after which the heat treatment was repeated. 2.3 Physical characterization The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy were analyzed by Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR) Spectrometer VERTEX 70 mid. The resolution is 0.16 cm−1. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed on a X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Max-3A) with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54178 Å) radiation at 40 kV and 30 mA. The samples were scanned over the 2θ ranges from 10° to 90° at the scan rate of 10° min−1. The elemental quantification and species analysis were studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific Escalab, 250Xi) equipped with a monochromated Al Kα (1486.6 eV) source. The spectra were background corrected using C1s 284.8 eV calibration. Survey scans were obtained using a pass energy of 100 eV while 20 eV pass energy were employed for the high resolution scans of specific elements. The Raman spectroscopy was carried out on a Raman spectrometer (Horiba, LabRAM HR Evolution) with an excitation wavelength of 532 nm. The surface areas were measured by Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms at 100 °K. All the samples were degassed by heating at 150 °C under vacuum prior to measuring. The field-emission scanning electron microscopic (FE-SEM) images were recorded on a Hitachi SU8220 (Japan) electron microscope. High-angle annular dark-field imaging aberration corrected STEM (HAADF-STEM) images and elemental mapping were collected using a transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL, JEM-2100F) equipped with EDX spectroscopy. The Fe K-edge was analyzed by extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra at beamline 1W2B of the Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility in fluorescence mode. The incident X-ray beam was monitored by an ionization chamber filled with N2, and the fluorescence signal was collected on a Lytle-type detector filled with Ar. The X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) data processing and EXAFS fitting were performed using Demeter [47]. 2.4 Electrochemical characterization Electrochemical characterizations by cyclic voltammetry (CV), dual electrode voltammetry (DECV) and rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) tests were conducted on a potentiostat instrument (PINE) in a conventional three-electrode cell system with a carbon stick counter electrode and a RHE reference electrode. The catalyst ink was prepared by ultrasonically blending (15 min) of 5 mg Fe-N-C in a solution containing 0.09 mL of H2O, 0.40 mL of ethanol, and 0.01 mL of 5 wt% Nafion to get a uniform ink. Afterwards, 15 μL of well-dispersed ink was carefully dropped on the RRDE electrode surface with a mass loading of 0.6 mg·cm−2, dried in air naturally for more than 30 min before the subsequent electrochemical tests. To evaluate the ORR activity, CV curves were carried out from 0.05 to 1.15 V with a scan rate of 50 mV·s−1 in O2/N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH or 0.5 M H2SO4 solutions. DECV was performed to obtain the ORR linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves at a scan rate of 5 mV·s−1 and a rotating speed of 1600 rpm in O2-saturated (or N2-saturated for obtaining the background curve) media. ORR durability was evaluated by CV successive sweeping between the potential of 0.6 to 1.0 V at a scan rate of 100 mV·s−1 in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH or 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolytes. For comparison, the commercial 40 wt% Pt/C (mass loading was 20 μgPt·cm−2) was also measured, under the same electrochemical testing conditions as for the Fe-N-C catalysts. Hydrogen peroxide yields and the electron transfer number (n) were calculated using the equations following (1) and (2): (1) H 2 O 2 % = 200 × I r / N I r / N + I d (2) n = 4 × I d I d + I d / N Herein, I r and I d are the disk and ring currents, respectively. N is the ring collection efficiency and the measured N value was 38%. To evaluate the OER activity, rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurement was performed to obtain the LSV curves at a scan rate of 5 mV·s−1 and a rotating speed of 1600 rpm in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH or 0.5 M H2SO4. For comparison, the Pt/C (IrO2) catalyst ink was also prepared by ultrasonically blending 4 mg Pt/C (IrO2) in a solution containing of H2O (0.36 mL), ethanol (1.60 mL), and 5 wt% Nafion (0.04 mL). The mass loadings of Pt/C and the IrO2 were 50 μgPt·cm−2 and 100 μgIrO2·cm−2, respectively, for OER. The other electrochemical testing conditions were the same as for Fe-N-C catalysts. The overall oxygen redox durability was evaluated by CV successive sweeping between the potential of 0.6 to 1.5 V at a scan rate of 100 mV·s−1 in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were conducted in a frequency range from 100 kHz to 100 mHz with an amplitude of 5 mV to make IR correction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structural analysis of Fe-N-C nanopheres Fig. 1 a illustrates the synthesis of Fe-N-C catalysts, in which 2,6-Diacetylpyridine (DAP) and 1,8-Diaminonaphthalene (DAN) were first polymerized via Schiff base condensation between diacetyl in DAP and diaminon in DAN to form bis(imino)-pyridine ligand based polymer. After addition of Iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), nanospherical poly{2,6-bis-[2-(N-(8-amino- naphthalen-1-yl)-imino)ethyl] pyridine} iron trichloride complex was obtained due to the coordinative interaction between the ligand of 2,6-bis-[2-(N-(8-amino- naphthalen-1-yl)-imino)ethyl] pyridine and Fe3+. The above synthesis was monitored by Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy (Fig. S1), indicating the successful formation of the bis(imino)-pyridine-ligand based polymer with iron complex. The received precursors were then pyrolyzed in the presence of N2 at certain temperatures. Following by harsh acid leaching and second pyrolysis in N2 to remove any containments and unstable species, Fe-N-C catalysts was finally prepared and denoted as Fe-N-C700, Fe-N-C800, Fe-N-C900 and Fe-N-C1000 according to the calcination temperature. Fig. 1b and c shows SEM images of Fe-N-C sample recorded before and after pyrolysis at 900 °C, for monitoring the changes in the morphology. It could be observed that both samples comprise nanospheres. Before pyrolysis, the average particle size of the spheres is around 250 nm (Fig. 1b). After pyrolysis and acid washing (Fig. 1c), the spheres shrink to 150 nm due to the carbonization of the polymeric precursor. To investigate the atomic state of Fe dopants, Cs-corrected HAADF-STEM measurements were carried out for the sample pyrolyzed at 900 °C. At the low magnification (Fig. 1d), the nanospheres show hollow like structures decorated with scattered big bright spots that should be Fe metallic phase formed during the pyrolysis. Most importantly, at the high magnification (Fig. 1e), number of bright spots were clearly observed on the outer layer of the spheres, due to the contrast difference between Fe and C, indicating that Fe single atoms have been distributed homogeneously. The high-resolution image (Fig. 1f) displays that the sphere's shell has the lattice fringe of graphite-type carbon layers, indicated by the interlayer spacing of 0.34 nm assigned to the (0 0 2) plane of graphite and a clear 3D hierarchical network with a great number of few-layer graphene grows in the carbon sphere. It is believed that such highly graphitic structure is very helpful for improving the conductivity and durability of materials as electrocatalysts. The element mapping images for C, Fe, N and O show a uniform distribution of the elements (Fig. S2). The phase analysis during synthesis of Fe-N-C catalysts was investigated by XRD. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the Fe-N-C sample after pyrolysis at 900 °C and without acid leaching demonstrates a very strong and sharp diffraction peak at around 44.76°, and two pianissimo diffraction peaks at 65.16° and 82.53°, corresponding to metallic Fe. The other pianissimo diffraction peaks at 33° and 42° could be assigned to Fe4N and Fe3O4, respectively. After the acid leaching, the Fe, Fe4N and iron oxide phases disappear, implying that the residual Fe species remained stable without agglomeration [48]. After the second pyrolysis, small peaks at 54° and 78° would be attributed to the presence of iron compounds such as FexN and FexC [49,50]. Meanwhile, the peak at around 43° sharpens, as FexN and FexC phases overlap with that (1 0 0) plane of graphitized carbon. In contrast, DAP-DAN900 without Fe ion after pyrolysis at 900 °C, display hard texture property and the broad peak at 25.68° shows graphite like structure, indicating its nature of graphite-like carbon nitride. Fig. 2b represents the XRD patterns for the Fe-N-C catalysts prepared at different heating temperatures. The patterns confirm that all the samples exhibit a very strong diffraction peak at around 26.3° together with some pianissimo diffraction peaks, corresponding to graphitic carbon. Mixture phases of Iron in the catalyst becomes stronger with increasing the calcination temperature. The specific surface area and porosity of the Fe-N-C samples were obtained by nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurement, as depicted in Fig. 2c. The curves between 0 and 1.0p/p0 obviously show type IV hysteresis loop indicating that there are abundant of micropores and mesopores in the catalyst material. The BET surface areas for different heat-treated Fe-N-C catalysts and DAP-DAN900 (Fe-free) are presented in Fig. S3. The surface areas of the Fe-N-C catalysts show dramatic increments compared with that of DAP-DAN900 where the surface area is only 37.17 m2·g−1. In fact, by increasing the heat treatment temperature up to 900 °C, the surface area sharply rises to a maximum of 1795.68 m2·g−1 in Fe-N-C900 before a dramatic fall to 1415.42 m2·g−1 at 1000 °C. It is clear, therefore, that the addition of iron resulted in highly porous catalysts with high specific surface areas. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) of the pore size distribution curves (Fig. 2d) derived from the N2 desorption branches also confirmed that the catalysts mainly include micropores and mesopores where the micropores and mesopores are mainly distributed over the range of 0.47–2 nm, and 2 nm to 50 nm, respectively. The Fe-N-C900 catalyst resulted a BJH average pore width of 3.48 nm and a single point total pore volume of 0.78 cm3·g−1 where the specific surface area of the single point test was 1403.84 m2·g−1. These values have been widely recognized as beneficial for an ample electrode/electrolyte interface for ion or charge accumulation performance during the ORR and OER processes [38]. To further analyze the composition and chemical state of Fe-N-C samples were analyzed by XPS. Taking Fe-N-C900 as a sample, the peaks in the survey spectrum (Fig. 3 a) are indexed to C 1 s (92.23 at%), N 1 s (3.45 at%), O 1 s (4.14 at%) and Fe 2p (0.21 at%). To further explore the bonding configuration, high resolution XPS spectra were also collected. The results are presented in Fig. 3b, c and d. The deconvolved C 1 s peaks (Fig. 3b) could be fitting into four peaks at 284.75, 285.90, 287.70 and 289.51 eV which could be attributed to CC (sp2 centers), CC (sp3 centers), CN groups, OCO groups (π–π* shake-up satellites), respectively [51]. The high-resolution N 1s spectrum (Fig. 3c) can be well fitted into four bonding types centered at 398.2, 399.0, 401.2, and 402.7 eV, which could be assigned to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, graphitic N, and oxidized N, respectively [52], in agreement with the N states in NC (NC). Fig. S4a-c shows the N 1s spectra for the catalysts prepared at the other pyrolysis temperatures. Table S1 highlights the calculated percentage composition of pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and oxidized-N for the catalysts prepared at different pyrolysis temperatures. It could be observed that the pyridinic and graphitic nitrogen contents increase by increasing the pyrolysis temperature. There is a big jump in the pyridinic nitrogen content from 15.97% in Fe-N-C800 to 23.66% in Fe-N-C900 reaching to a slightly higher value (24.71%) in Fe-N-C1000. Meanwhile, the graphitic nitrogen content for Fe-N-C900 was 53.11%, close to that of Fe-N-C1000 (55.94%). These high graphitic and pyridinic N contents of the Fe-N-C900 catalyst can effectively promote the ORR and OER catalyzing processes [53]. It is worth noting that although Fe-N-C1000 shows slightly higher pyridinic and graphitic nitrogen contents, its surface area is much lower than the Fe-N-C900 counterpart as shown in Fig. S3d. The Fe 2p spectra (Fig. 3d) can be assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and could be fitted into one peak at 711.3 eV representing Fe-Nx [33]. It was revealed that Fe-Nx sites dominantly catalyze ORR via 4-electron (4e−) pathway, thus exerting a major role for high ORR activity [54]. To efficiently reveal the defect level and the degree of graphitization for the Fe-N-C catalysts, the Raman spectra of the catalysts prepared at different heating temperatures were recorded, as demonstrated in Fig. S5. The D-band, known as sp3 hybridized C atoms (which indicates the defects or disorders in the carbon structure) displays a maximum ranging between 1250 cm−1 and 1468 cm−1. On the other hand, the G-band (also known as a stretching vibration in the plane of sp2 hybridized C atoms) shows a peak over the range of 1508 cm−1 to 1640 cm−1. The ratio of the D-band to G-band is often used to reflect the defect level and crystallinity of carbon materials [55]. A decrease in the ratio of ID/IG represents an enhancement in the degree of graphitization resulting in more crystallized graphite. As it could be observed from Fig. S5, by increasing the heating temperature of the samples, the ratio of ID/IG decreases, in general. Therefore, it could be concluded that the higher pyrolysis temperature, the more graphitic structure would be formed. This ensures the presence of defect-rich points on the surface of graphite carbon and hence, more active sites would be exposed which play an important role in promoting ORR and OER processes [56]. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Fe-N-C nanoshperes for ORR and OER ORR activity of the prepared catalysts was carried out using LSV. Fig. 4 a, b illustrates that the oxygen reduction performance positively shifted with the increasing of the pyrolysis temperature from 700 °C to 900 °C but slightly reversed when the temperature was further increased to 1,000 °C. The Fe-N-C900 catalyst shows best electrochemical oxygen reduction catalytic performance in both acidic and alkaline solutions. The onset potential is 1.09 V and the half-wave potential reaches to 0.91 V in 0.1 M KOH for ORR (Fig. 4a) which is 32 mV higher than that of commercial Pt/C (half-wave potential of 0.88 V). In contrast, in 0.5 M H2SO4 (Fig. 4b), an onset potential of 0.96 V and a half-wave potential of 0.80 V were achieved. The limiting current for the Fe-N-C900 electrode is much larger than the other catalysts, and it is comparable to that of Pt/C in both alkaline and acidic solutions (Fig. 4a, b). The difference in limiting currents could be attributed to different factors such as the accessible Fe-N-C active sites Fe-Nx and pyridine-N [34]. The hydrogen peroxide yield (%) and the electron transfer number (n) of per oxygen molecule were calculated by analyzing the ring and disk currents and plotted as a function of potential (Fig. S6). In an alkaline electrolyte (Fig. S6a), the curves show an average n value of 3.988 but for an acidic electrolyte the calculated average value for n is 3.995 (Fig. S6b) in the potential window of 0.1–0.9 V. Therefore, the ORR on the Fe-N-C900 catalyst in the both electrolytes follows the four-electron-transfer pathway to water like Pt/C. As shown in Fig. S6a, the yield of hydrogen peroxide species in 0.1 M KOH solution is less than 2.50% in the measured potential range from 0.1 to 0.9 V. In the potential range of 0.08–0.42 V, the yield is higher than Pt/C, but it has been effectively suppressed in the potential window of 0.42–0.9 V demonstrating much lower values compared to Pt/C approaching to 0%. In 0.5 M H2SO4 solution (Fig. S6b), the hydrogen peroxide yield is less than 2% over the potentials ranging from 0.1 to 0.9 V, showing close values to that of Pt/C. We also assessed the electrochemical stability of Fe-N-C900 following the accelerated durability test protocol by the cycling potential between 0.6 V and 1.0 V at 100 mV s−1, as represented in Fig. S6. After 15,000 cycles, the half-wave potentials for Fe-N-C900 and Pt/C decreased about 16 mV and 34 mV, respectively, in 0.1 M KOH solution (Fig. S6c). In 0.5 M H2SO4 solution (Fig. S6d), the half-wave potential for Fe-N-C900 dropped about 22 mV, compared to a 40 mV fall for Pt/C, after 15,000 cycles. These results indicate that Fe-N-C is more durable for ORR in contrast to Pt/C in both acidic and alkaline solutions. Meanwhile, after 15,000 cycles the ORR performance of Fe-N-C900 is much better than Pt/C both in acidic and alkaline media. The OER performance was also evaluated in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 solutions. Fig. 4c confirms that the Fe-N-C900 is significantly active for the OER with an onset potential of about 1.42 V at 1.0 mA·cm−2 in 0.1 M KOH solution. In addition, Fe-N-C900 needs potentials only about 1.61 V, 1.63 V and 1.64 V to reach the current densities of 10, 20 and 30 mA·cm−2, respectively, in 0.1 M KOH solution. These values are much better than that of commercial Pt/C and IrO2, Pt/C with the onset potential of about 1.59 V at 1.0 mA·cm−1, needing potentials of about 1.76 V, 1.80 V and 1.83 V to reach current densities of 10, 20 and 30 mA·cm−2, respectively. While IrO2 needs potentials of about 1.64 V, 1.71 V and 1.77 V to deliver the current densities of 10, 20 and 30 mA·cm−2, respectively. Fig. S7a shows the Tafel plots for the examined samples in 0.1 M KOH, the slope for Fe-N-C900 (55.45 mV dec−1) is much lower than that of Pt/C (134.76 mV dec−1) and IrO2 (100.26 mV dec−1) indicating a much higher rate of OER at Fe-N-C900. Fig. 4d confirms that the Fe-N-C900 is also highly active for OER in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution with the onset potential of about 1.52 V. It needs potentials of about 1.57 V, 1.65 V and 1.70 V to deliver the current densities of 5, 10 and 20 mA·cm−2, respectively, excelling the commercial Pt/C in performance. To investigate the stability of Fe-N-C900, we conducted a chronopotentiometry test for OER with the anodic current density fixed at 5 mA·cm−2 with a rotating speed of 1600 rpm in both N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 solutions over 10 h (Fig. S7). The test revealed that OER potentials of the Fe-N-C900 catalyst remained very stable by a gentle rise of only 5 mV (Fig. S7c) and 17 mV (Fig. S7d) at the current density of 5 mA·cm−2 in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 solutions, respectively. The results are in good agreement with the OER catalytic activity values. On the basis of aforementioned results, the Fe-N-C900 sample not only exhibit the best ORR but also the best OER catalytic activity; this material thus affords the best overall bifunctional catalytic activity among the samples investigated in this work. The overall oxygen redox activity (ΔE = Ej=10 − E1/2) is a critical criterion for assessing the overall bifunctional catalytic activity of a catalyst. A lower value represents better overall bifunctional catalytic activity. Interestingly, the oxygen ΔE of the Fe-N-C900 catalyst (Fig. 4e, f) is only 0.70 V in 0.1 M KOH and 0.86 V in 0.5 M H2SO4 which are much better than 0.88 V and 0.96 V for Pt/C and 1.06 V and 1.18 V for IrO2, respectively. To further verify the stability of oxygen redox activity of the Fe-N-C900 catalyst, the accelerated stability test of the Fe-N-C900 catalysts under the more harsh condition with the cycling potential range from 0.6 to 1.5 V vs. RHE at the scan rate of 100 mV·s−1 in O2-staturated 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 and characterized the difference of catalyst structure before and after stability test by Raman and XPS measurements to elucidate the concern on the stability of our Fe-N-C catalyst for oxygen redox reaction. Fig. 5 shows the overall activity of our Fe-N-C for ORR and OER before and after potential cycles. The overall oxygen redox activity (ΔE) of our Fe-N-C900 catalyst after 5000 10,000 and 15,000 potential cycles in 0.1 M KOH slightly decay 3.85%, 10.83%, 13.39%, respectively and only decay 8.07%, 18.13%, 30.99%, respectively in more harsher 0.5 M H2SO4. After 15,000 cycle, the catalyst still display a good performance that ΔE is 0.80 V and 1.12 V in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively. It indicates that our catalyst has an excellent stability and better than the results reported previously, even in the wider potential range sweep and more potential cycle number, although there is a big difference between test protocol conditions reported such as potential range, methods (CV or LSV) and cycle number, it is hard to summarize the stability performance reported into a table shown here. In order to further verify the stability of our catalyst, Raman and XPS were carried out to investigate the difference of our catalyst before and after the stability test. It is well known that the degradation of Fe-N-C based Catalysts is mainly contributed to the carbon corrosion and Fe leaching or Fe-centered configuration destruction [57,58]. From the Raman analysis as shown in Fig. S8, ID/IG, an indicator of defect degree of graphite, is 0.79 for the original state, after 15,000 cycles which slightly increase to 0.89 in 0.1 M KOH and 1.05 in 0.5 M H2SO4, demonstrating that the carbon corrosion exactly occurs in the test. On the other hand, from the XPS analysis (Table S2), the content of C, N, Fe also decrease slightly and O content increase by the comparison before and after test, indicating the concurrence of carbon corrosion and Fe-leaching. However, no dramatic change of catalyst structure can be detected. That characterizations also prove the stability of our catalyst. The outstanding bifunctional performance of the catalyst places it the best catalyst, compared with other state-of-the-art electrocatalysts reported as shown in Table 1. 3.3 Identification of active sites of Fe-N-C nanospheres To unravel the chemical state of Fe atoms, we performed Fe K-edge X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) measurements. Fig. 6 a obviously signifies that the Fe-N-C900 shows a different X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) pattern from the other standard samples of iron foil, Fe3C and Fe2N, indicating a different structure for the Fe-N-C900 catalyst. Fourier transform (FT) of EXAFS (Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure) in Fig. 6b show no obvious Fe-Fe bond in Fe-N-C900, remarking that majority of Fe exists in the form of individual atom. The strong peak at ∼1.5 Å and the weak peak at 2.5 Å are contributed by FeC bond [59] and FeN bond [60], respectively. A further curve fitting using Demeter was performed to obtain the structural parameters of Fe-N-C900 as displayed in Fig. 6c. The FeN coordination number is 5.0 (±0.2), the bond length R(Å) is 1.97 (±0.02), and the Debye-Waller factor σ2 (Å2) is 0.011 (±0.003). It is believed that the configuration of the Fe-Nx sites with different coordination structure can significantly affect the intrinsic electrocatalytic activity for ORR and OER [35,61]. In order to identify the catalytic role of the specific five-coordinated single iron atom in the Fe-N-C catalysts, SCN− ion as a probe was introduced into electrolyte to poison Fe-Nx sites in catalyzing ORR due to the fact that SCN− has strong coordinative capability to Fe ion [62]. Fig. 7 shows the compare of the polarization curves of Fe-N-C900 for ORR and OER in the 0.1 M KOH or 0.5 M H2SO4 solution before and after adding 0.05 M SCN− ions. It can be seen (in Fig. 7a and b) that the E1/2 of Fe-N-C900 decreases significantly by about 58.1 mV, 83 mV in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 solution respectively, after the addition 0.05 M KSCN. Correspondingly, the onset potentials for ORR also shift negatively. It also can be seen (in Fig. 7c and d) that the potential of Fe-N-C900 at 10 mA·cm−1 increases significantly by about 100 mV, 97 mV in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 solution respectively, after the addition of 0.05 M KSCN. The dramatically depression of catalytic activity can be attributed to the blocking of Fe-Nx active sites by SCN− in catalyzing ORR and OER. This result distinctly substantiate that Fe-Nx coordination sites should be responsible for the ORR and OER kinetics of Fe-N-C catalysts. On the basis of the above results, we believe that the super catalytic activity of Fe-N-C can be attributed to the Fe monatomic nanoparticles Fe-Nx sites and pyridinic-N active sites, it was revealed that Fe-Nx sites dominantly catalyze ORR via 4-electron (4e−) pathway, exerting a major role for high ORR activity; high specific surface is a beneficial for an ample electrode/electrolyte interface for ion or charge accumulation performance. It was revealed that the pyrolysis temperature strongly affects the performance of the catalyst. In fact, the highest ORR and OER activities were achieved at a pyrolysis temperature of 900 °C where the performances surpassed the commercial Pt/C in both alkaline and acidic media. From the XPS analysis, we can know that the difference in pyrolysis temperature lead to the change of the content of the variety of nitrogen means different amounts of active sites. So the catalyst pyrolyzed at 900 °C (Fe-N-C900) exhibits the highest active sites and thus it exhibits the highest ORR and OER activity. 4 Conclusion A new precursor of Fe coordinated bis(imino)-pyridine ligand based polymer was successfully developed using 2, 6-Diacetylpyridine (DAP) and 1,8-Diamino-naphthalene (DAN) as precursors for both carbon and nitrogen together with FeCl3·6H2O as the iron source for obtaining high-performance and durable nonprecious metal oxygen catalysts for ORR and OER, which can efficiently perform in both alkaline and acidic media. The excellent ORR and OER performances and stability of the Fe-N-C900 single iron atoms catalysts could be attributed to the following outstanding features: (a) uniform dispersion of metal atoms; (b) large numbers of nitrogen functional pyridinic-N and graphitic groups within the carbon framework; (c) the precise five-coordinated Fe-N5 sites; (d) a high specific surface area (1796 m2·g−1) (e) a high degree of graphitized carbon. So the introduced catalyst is among the best reported bifunctional electrocatalysts and may open promising insights for the future of metal-air batteries and fuel cell devices. coredata.dc:description: In spite of the recent advancements, rational design and synthesis of non-precious metal oxygen redox catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in both alkaline and acidic media is still a crucial challenge for the development of rechargeable metal-air batteries and regenerative fuel cells. Heteroatom doped carbon-based materials exhibit a promising strategy to achieve the bifunctionality within one catalyst. Herein, we report a highly efficient Fe-N-C oxygen redox catalyst derived from a new class of Fe coordinated bis(imino)-pyridine ligand based polymer synthesized via Schiff base condensation between 2,6-diacetylpyridine and 1,8-diaminonaphthalene. The Fe-N-C catalyst prepared by this precursor without templates or supports is characterized by spherical structure, ultrahigh specific surface area up to 1796.0 m2/g, a high degree of graphitization and atomically dispersed five-coordinated Fe-N5 sites. These unique features endow the catalyst with outperforming performance for ORR and OER in terms of remarkable activity and stability in both alkaline and acidic media. The overall oxygen redox activity (ΔE = Ej=10 − E1/2) (0.70 V in alkaline media and 0.86 V in acidic media) of the catalyst for both ORR and OER is much higher than those of none precious metal catalysts previously reported. These outstanding features remark the great possibility of the introduced catalyst for the practical application.
coredata.dc:title: Ultra-high surface area graphitic Fe-N-C nanospheres with single-atom iron sites as highly efficient non-precious metal bifunctional catalysts towards oxygen redox reactions
